awd_titl_txt: POSE: Phase I:  Establishing an Ecosystem for Open-source Educational Computer Aided Design (CAD) Models
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded by Pathways to Enable Open-Source Ecosystems (POSE) which seeks to harness the power of open-source development for the creation of new technology solutions to problems of national and societal importance. During the past decade, many K-12 schools have established makerspaces with three dimensional (3D) printers, digital die cutters, and other fabrication tools. To facilitate effective use of school makerspaces, an open-source ecosystem is being developed to provide students and educators with curated, carefully reviewed Computer-Aided Design (CAD) models. The ecosystem will be structured around an existing open-source Educational CAD Model Repository. The long-term ecosystem includes a clearinghouse for CAD models with (a) peer-reviewed articles describing classroom use, and (b) the models linked to associated downloadable files in the repository. Accepted practitioner-based articles will be published in a new journal, Educational Fabrication & Design (ED&F), established as one component of the ecosystem. The project’s novelty is that educational CAD models will be externally reviewed, tested, and validated before they are added to the repository. The widespread availability of design and fabrication tools in K-12 makerspaces offers the potential to create new objects and remix existing designs. Science, mathematics, and engineering educators and their students will benefit from access to carefully curated models and associated instructional materials. The resulting open-source ecosystem’s impact will increase effective use of K-12 makerspaces across all of the relevant disciplines and lead to broader literacy in design and fabrication.

During the one year scoping activities of this project, the International Technology and Engineering Education Association (ITEEA) will revise its flagship curriculum, Engineering by Design (EbD © ITEEA), to incorporate the ecosystem constructed around the repository of CAD models. More than 5,000 teachers and more than 50,000 students using the curriculum can engage with the models integrated as a keystone element of the revised curriculum. In addition, the Fab Foundation, established through the Center for Atoms and Bits at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), will collaborate to engage a network of 2,000 Fabrication Laboratories (FabLabs) in this process. The eduFAB Network, an educational extension of the Fab Foundation, will work to coordinate activities across the respective disciplines.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The advent of affordable tools such as 3D printers and microcontrollers has made it feasible to develop open hardware designs for scientific tools and instruments that can be freely replicated, used, and modified. Open hardware designs have enhanced the capabilities of university research laboratories through fabrication of scientific tools that can be customized and that also yield significant cost savings. The goal of this initiative is to extend the benefits of open hardware to K–12 schools.

The National Technology Leadership Society (NTLS), a coalition of twelve national teacher education associations, established an Educational CAD Model Library (CAD Library) for K-12 schools. The CAD Library was developed by the Make to Learn Laboratory at the University of Virginia working in collaboration with the University of Virginia Library and the University’s Department of Computer Science. Objects in the CAD Library are housed in an instance of the Dataverse, open-source database software, managed by the University of Virginia Library. An application interface (API) can be used to add objects to the repository and retrieve them. Each item published in the repository is assigned a Document Object Identifier (DOI). 

The CAD Library provides a mechanism for publication of peer-reviewed open hardware designs for K-12 schools. A Curator’s Council appointed by the NTLS STEM associations manages the review and publication process.  The Curator’s Council established standards for the review and publication of educational objects. In that regard, the role of a CAD Library curator encompasses some of the functions of a journal editor. However, curators also actively promote the development of open hardware objects designed for use in schools, a responsibility that aligns with the role of a museum curator.

In the same way that journals serve as an engine to generate, validate, and disseminate scientific knowledge, the peer-reviewed CAD Library is designed to serve as an engine to generate and disseminate innovations developed by K-12 educators and students. This, in turn, can lead to a cycle of continual improvement as each generation builds upon and extends designs developed by the previous generation.

The most successful open hardware communities in post-secondary settings have formed around projects with a large user base. For example, open hardware designs for 3D-printed microscopes are widely adopted by research laboratories and medical centers. To build similar communities around open hardware at the K-12 level, some of the most successful open hardware designs are being adapted for K12 use. The OpenFlexure microscope is being adapted for use in the K-12 schools with the endorsement of and support of the OpenFlexure principal investigator, Richard Bowman.   To build a parallel community for K-12 education, a series of microscopy clubs for youth are being formed. The most successful microscope designs will be published in the CAD Library so that these designs will be available to other schools nationally.

This strategy aims to build capacity for the development of after-school engineering clubs in which high school students collaborate with science teachers to develop or adapt open hardware tools and instruments for K-12 science classes. The International Society for Technology and Engineering Educators Association (ITEEA) can then disseminate the most promising tools for replication through incorporation into its Engineering by Design curriculum taught by ITEEA technology and engineering educators.

Through this process, teachers and students benefit by customizing open hardware scientific instruments for local use, gaining a deeper understanding of the principles underlying scientific instrument design and fabrication. This hands-on experience prepares students for careers in the STEM workforce while providing schools with valuable resources for science classes.
